ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: By taking this course, I learned about some of the aspects crucial to contract formation and enforcement such as the practice of good faith. The course discussed the matters of negotiation in arbitration, mediation, and conciliation that function within the realm of private law, specifically arbitration at the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris. This course also enlightened me on the practice of game theory to understand contract enforcement by applying the strategies within simple games like prisoner's dilemma and transactional exchanges of Hohfeldian entitlements between two parties.
This course teaches a lot about economics/game theory and how it relates to contract law. Additionally you will learn how to engage in Parisian culture.
Contract design and the details of arbitration, diving into negotiation tactics using game theory and how parties behave
I was able to expand upon my knowledge of economics, especially in a more realistic manner by taking into account various legal systems and the incentives to follow them.
Game theory and legal analysis of contractual exchange. Insights into French universities and French life in general.

I developed in depth knowledge regarding contract law: how contracts are made, arbitration, negotiation, game theory, and a broad comparison between contracts and law in the United States in comparison to France.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I thoroughly enjoyed the mixture of teaching styles embedded in this course that allowed students to engage with French and American professors. However, I think teaching styles varied in a confusing manner. It may be helpful for all professors to have the same teaching style: a few readings before the class and a lecture with slides during the class. Also, I wished there was more transparency about the grading of this course. The short time span to receive feedback and questions about the material in response to that feedback made it difficult to grasp the course material. 

Also, the fundamental aspect of having a coalition of American and French students in this class made this class unforgettable and an incomparable experience. Learning about what is included in a typical French eduction compared to American education was beyond fascinating. I had the opportunity to learn and ask questions to the French students about the course content and the greater experience of spending the summer in Paris. The greatest strength of this course is undoubtedly the opportunities for the French and American students to interact.

Strength: beautiful location (Paris) for the summer, very easy to connect with French students
Weaknesses: not a lot of transparency, course organization could use a little more effort.
The professors were strengths, weaknesses are maybe lack of peer tutors

The strengths of this course are that it teaches very interesting legal material by legal professionals which makes for a unique experience. However, this course was highly disorganized in terms of never getting our grades for assignments back, no clear dates for things like exams (our final exam schedule was changed and we were told the change less than 24 hours before our exam which it had been increased and made for harder exam preparation). Also, this course is taught for 4 hours every day with very few small breaks 4 days a week. Given this time schedule, there was too much information crammed into sessions. The material is all very new and can be hard to digest so it made the class hard to follow because there were too many things being taught in one day, every day. I would suggest keeping students updated and providing feedback in a timely manner for class assignments so they can properly prepare for exams. I also suggest providing the class syllabus ahead of time and making it more detailed so students can be aware of how much each assignment is weighted as well as exams (we were never given this information). Also, the professors should be more prepared when coming to class, as great as some of them were, there were a few professors that did not explain their material well, went too fast, and did not have slides prepared. So, while having multiple professors is a strength of the program, I do believe there should be a priority on making sure they come to class prepared.
Well structured, highly thoughtful content and practice with different professors from around the world.
The variety of professors was greatly appreciated to see so many different perspectives, but the amount of class hours was rather long.
Upload all course material to canvas for digital access. Shorter class time (10-1pm recommended).

I think that a strength of this course was the professors who prepared magnificent lectures for us and challenged us to really implement the knowledge we were learning. However, I think a weakness of the course was the lack of feedback we received. We went through most of the course not knowing how we had done on our psets or what the exam would look like and I think it hindered our performance on the final exam.,

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, another students would benefit from the unique experience of a grad school course during their undergrad years as well as the extraordinary opportunity to learn from French students.
Absolutely! Spending a summer in Paris was an incredible experience. Be sure to take advantage of all that Paris has to offer - it goes by really fast.
Yes, it was in Paris

Yes, I would because you learn valuable skills in an environment conducive to higher learning. You get to learn alongside french graduate business and law students and it is really cool hearing their perspectives and ideas.
Absolutely. Opened my mind to sooo much of the world and how the professional world interacts with eachother.
I would greatly recommend this course, not only because of the interesting material, but also how well organized and put together the experience as whole was abroad.
Yes. It is a great way to explore a new culture and to learn the basics of the intersection of law and economics for those interested in law with a background in economics.

I sure would! Based on this course I realized that I definitely have a passion for law and would like to pursue a career in law. I met wonderful people who were also interested in the intersection of law and economics. In addition, I had the opportunity to learn about French Law  in comparison to the U.S. which was incredibly captivating.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: This course previewed what I may study following my undergraduate studies at Yale, thus I assume the lessons I learned over the last five weeks will be topics I will revisit long after this summer. I will revisit the intuitions behind the economics of the last few weeks, but more frequently I will use the lessons we learned about liability and damage reimbursement outside of my career or academic endeavors. I am confident the knowledge I obtained from this course will be applicable to my life throughout the future.
Living abroad allows for a lot of personal reflection. While we learned a lot in the class, I think the biggest takeaway from this program is the experience of living in Paris for the summer.
Soo much. Lets see!
This course essentially served as an introduction to law for me, and as I pursue a pre-law track, as well as help in my further studies in economics.
Hopefully I can find a job in Paris.
I am certain that all the knowledge I gained in this course will not only aid my success in future courses at Yale but also in law school.
